[LIST_ITEM] Some contraceptives containing nonoxynol-9 (N-9) might increase the risk for HIV sexual transmission.
[LIST_ITEM] Three randomized controlled trials of N-9 failed to demonstrate any protection against HIV infection
[LIST_ITEM] One trial showed an increased risk
[LIST_ITEM] N-9 contraceptives also failed to protect against infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae and also Failed to protect against Chlamydia trachomatis in two randomized trials

[LIST_ITEM] The 2002 STD treatment guidelines state that condoms lubricated with spermicides are no more effective than other lubricated condoms in protecting against the transmission of HIV infection and other STDs

[LIST_ITEM] CDC recommends that previously purchased condoms lubricated with N-9 spermicide continue to be distributed provided the condoms have not passed their expiration date. The amount of N-9 on a spermicide-lubricated condom is small relative to the doses tested in the studies in Africa and the use of N-9--lubricated condoms is preferable to using no condom at all.
